title: J05-4003

sentences.text: We present a novel method for discovering parallel sentences in comparable , non-parallel corpora .
We train a maximum entropy classifier that , given a pair of sentences , can reliably determine whether or not they are translations of each other .
Using this approach , we extract parallel data from large Chinese , Arabic , and English non-parallel newspaper corpora .
We evaluate the quality of the extracted data by showing that it improves the performance of a state-of-the-art statistical machine translation system .
We also show that a good-quality MT system can be built from scratch by starting with a very small parallel corpus -LRB- 100,000 words -RRB- and exploiting a large non-parallel corpus .
Thus , our method can be applied with great benefit to language pairs for which only scarce resources are available .

Entity-our_method.description: A novel approach for discovering parallel sentences in comparable and non-parallel corpora by training a maximum entropy classifier that determines whether two given sentences are translations of each other.

summary: We present a novel method for discovering parallel sentences in comparable , non-parallel corpora . We train a maximum entropy classifier that , given a pair of sentences , can reliably determine whether or not they are translations of each other . Using this approach , we extract parallel data from large Chinese , Arabic , and English non-parallel newspaper corpora . We evaluate the quality of the extracted data by showing that it improves the performance of a state-of-the-art statistical machine translation system . We also show that a good-quality MT system can be built from scratch by starting with a very small parallel corpus -LRB- 100,000 words -RRB- and exploiting a large non-parallel corpus . Thus , our method can be applied with great benefit to language pairs for which only scarce resources are available .

Predicate-train.label: train
Predicate-train.description: To train means to utilize a subject's expertise or resources to develop or refine an object, often resulting in the improvement of its performance, accuracy, or effectiveness. The predicate 'train' implies a causal relationship between the subject and the object, suggesting that the subject plays a role in shaping or guiding the development of the object.

Predicate-can_reliably_determine_whether.label: can reliably determine whether or not they are translations of each other
Predicate-can_reliably_determine_whether.description: This predicate indicates that the subject has the ability to accurately identify and distinguish between pairs of linguistic expressions (e.g., texts or phrases), determining whether they are equivalent translations of each other. The connection between the subject and object lies in the subject's capacity for comparative analysis, allowing it to recognize similarities and differences between the two expressions.

Predicate-extract.label: extract
Predicate-extract.description: To obtain or derive a specific portion or aspect of something from its original form. This predicate indicates that the subject is being used to generate or produce the object, which may be a summary, key points, or other condensed representation.

Predicate-show_that.label: show that
Predicate-show_that.description: To demonstrate or prove the existence of something (typically an idea, concept, or quality), often through evidence, examples, or demonstration.

Predicate-be_built_from_scratch_by_start.label: be built from scratch by starting with
Predicate-be_built_from_scratch_by_start.description: The predicate 'be built from scratch by starting with' indicates that the subject was created or developed using a foundation or base provided by the object. The object serves as the initial point, and the process of building or creating the subject begins with this foundation.

Predicate-exploiting.label: exploiting
Predicate-exploiting.description: The predicate 'exploiting' indicates that the subject (an entity or a process) makes use of, takes advantage of, or derives benefits from the object. It implies a relationship where the subject leverages the object's characteristics, properties, or resources to achieve its goals or purposes.

Predicate-can_be_applied_with_great_bene.label: can be applied with great benefit to
Predicate-can_be_applied_with_great_bene.description: This predicate indicates that the subject has a positive impact or outcome when used on or related to the object. It suggests a direct and significant advantage or benefit resulting from applying the subject to the object.

Predicate-use.label: use
Predicate-use.description: To employ or utilize something for a specific purpose or function. The predicate 'use' indicates that the subject (an entity, process, or system) applies its capabilities to achieve an outcome or accomplish a task with respect to the object.

Predicate-present.label: present
Predicate-present.description: The predicate 'present' indicates that the subject and object are equivalent or identical, often implying a sense of novelty, innovation, or introduction. It suggests that what was previously unknown or absent has been brought forward into existence.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject concept is a specific instance or subclass of the object concept. It represents an is-a relationship, where the subject is more precise and detailed than the object.
